header.title: EDITOR'S NOTE: Australian Journal of Parapsychology

central_thesis: This editorial note details the Australian Journal of Parapsychology's strategic direction, emphasizing its commitment to reader satisfaction and academic rigor. It announces the new AIPR President, Hannah Jenkins, presents key findings from a recent subscriber survey, and outlines future content adjustments, including the introduction of a supplementary newsletter, The A.I.P.R. News, to cater to specific reader interests such as paranormal investigations and experiences.

structure_content.summary: The editorial begins by welcoming Hannah Jenkins as the new AIPR President, highlighting her plans for the Institute and the journal's role in serving subscribers' interests.
The editor discusses the continuous effort to maintain the journal's high standards, inviting reader feedback as crucial for comparison with international parapsychological journals.

Presents a quantitative overview of responses from a survey enclosed with the December issue, covering topics like technicality, transpersonal contributions, paranormal investigations, first-hand accounts, book reviews, and subscriptions to other journals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Analysis of Survey Feedback and Content Adjustments
structure_content.summary: Interprets the survey results, noting that most readers find the journal's technical level appropriate. It specifically addresses demands for more anthropology-related articles, diverse authors, paranormal investigations, and first-hand accounts, while confirming satisfaction with book reviews.

Announces the upcoming launch of The A.I.P.R. News, a free newsletter for subscribers, intended to feature reports of paranormal experiences and investigations between main journal issues, as well as news and event reviews.
The editorial board expresses hope that readers will enjoy the current 2007 Journal issue and the forthcoming inaugural A.I.P.R. News.

key_concepts.definition: Australian Institute of Parapsychological Research; the parent organization for the journal, with new projects and services designed for its subscribers.
A publication committed to maintaining high standards in parapsychological research, seeking reader feedback to compare favorably with overseas journals.
A mechanism used by the journal to gather feedback from subscribers on content, technicality, and interests, with over 20% readership response.
A type of content requested by 73% of survey respondents, including 'ghost-hunts' and haunting-type research, which the journal plans to address in a new newsletter.

A new supplementary newsletter, free to Journal subscribers, designed to provide occasional reports of paranormal experiences and investigations, as well as news and reviews of current events in the paranormal world, launching in 2007.
A type of content related to experiences beyond the personal self; 55% of readers indicated "No" or "It was OK as it is" regarding seeing more of this.

practical_system.description: The 'system' outlined is the editorial and publication strategy of the Australian Journal of Parapsychology, designed to respond to and integrate reader feedback to enhance subscriber value and maintain academic standards. It involves a continuous feedback loop through surveys and direct communication, leading to adaptations in content and the introduction of new publication channels.
tools: Reader feedback surveys (e.g., enclosed with issues)
The Australian Journal of Parapsychology itself as the main publication vehicle
The A.I.P.R. News newsletter as a supplementary publication for specific content
The AIPR website (www.aiprinc.org/index.asp) for further information and resources
External glossaries for technical terms (e.g., Thalbourne's, www.mdani.demon.co.uk/para/paraglos.htm) to address readability concerns.
rituals: Conducting annual reader surveys to gauge subscriber satisfaction and preferences
Engaging with subscriber feedback for continuous improvement of journal content and services
Introducing new publications (e.g., A.I.P.R. News) to diversify content delivery based on specific reader demands
Maintaining a balance between peer-reviewed research and more accessible reports on paranormal experiences.

relevant_quotes.text: On behalf of our editorial team, I welcome Hannah Jenkins in her new role as AIPR President, and wish her a long and productive stay with us.

My goal is not only to ensure that it meets your needs and expectations, but also that it compares favourably with parapsychological journals published overseas. To do that effectively, I need your feedback.
Here are the results: 1. Is the journal too technical? 86% said “No” or “It was OK as it is”
Would you like to see more reports on paranormal investigations? (e.g., 'ghost-hunts', haunting-type research, etc.) 73% said "Yes"

These results mean that the vast majority of readers are not challenged by the technical nature of the articles, but one person thought there'd be room for a glossary of technical and statistical terms.

Given the overwhelming support for the journal as it currently stands, and given that we have always intended to maintain a journal that meets the expectations of the scientific community, we will continue to feature peer-reviewed research articles and book reviews in the journal, but for all subscribers (especially those who asked for it), we plan to present occasional reports of paranormal experiences and investigations in a free newsletter, The A.I.P.R. News.
We, on the editorial board, hope that you enjoy both this first issue of the Journal for 2007, and the inaugural issue of The A.I.P.R. News, coming soon.

critical_analysis.relevance: This editorial is highly relevant to the readership of the Australian Journal of Parapsychology as it directly addresses their feedback and outlines significant changes and additions to the publication strategy. It serves as a transparent communication of the journal's commitment to its community and its evolving content strategy, including a new President and newsletter. For the broader field of parapsychology, it offers insight into reader interests and the operational challenges of a specialized academic journal.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the current and prospective subscribers of the Australian Journal of Parapsychology. Additionally, it addresses authors, contributors, and potentially the broader parapsychological academic community interested in the journal's direction and the interests of its readership.
